nodes.text: The impacts of retirement savings policies on total wealth accumulation depend on whether they operate via active choice versus passive (automatic) choice
Subsidies for tax-preferred retirement accounts (price incentives) primarily induce asset shifting across accounts rather than large increases in total saving
Automatic contributions (employer or government-mandated contributions that occur if individuals take no action) substantially increase total saving for most individuals

Event-study of 4.1 million firm switches: a DKr 1 increase in employer contributions raises total pension contributions by ~0.95 DKr and raises total saving by ~0.78 DKr (holding total compensation fixed)

Regression-discontinuity on 1998 Mandatory Savings Plan (MSP): the MSP induced near-complete pass-through into total saving for the affected income bins (threshold estimates ~0.85-1.27 depending on measure), implying mandated contributions raised total saving
1999 policy: reduction in the capital-pension subsidy caused mean individual capital pension contributions to fall by DKr 2,449 (about 48% of prior mean) for top-bracket taxpayers

Heterogeneous response to the 1999 subsidy: only ~19% of prior contributors actively reoptimized (most of those exited capital pensions), while ~81% left contributions unchanged, implying a large passive majority with respect to subsidy changes

Crowd-out estimates from the 1999 reform: ~57% of forgone capital pension contributions shifted to annuity pensions; conditional on reduced total pension contributions, ~99% of retirement contributions came from money that would have been in taxable accounts, implying each DKr of tax expenditure on subsidies generated roughly 0.01 DKr of net new saving (95% CI upper bound ~0.28 DKr)

Data and identification: administrative panel for Denmark 1995-2009 (41 million person-year observations); methods include firm-switch event studies, RD at MSP eligibility, diﬀerence-in-differences around tax cutoff, IV/threshold and robustness checks

Heterogeneity: 'active savers' (who respond to price subsidies and offset automatic contributions) are disproportionately older, wealthier, and more financially sophisticated (e.g., economics majors); 'passive savers' (~85%) are less responsive to subsidies but respond to automatic contributions

Long-run eﬀects: the employer-contribution-induced increases in saving persist for at least a decade and translate into substantially higher accumulated wealth at retirement (example: switching to a firm with 5 percentage points higher employer contributions raised accrued wealth by ~25% of annual labor income by age 60 in the sample)

Conclusion: automatic contribution policies are more eﬀective than price subsidies in raising total saving because (a) subsidies induce relatively few individuals to respond, (b) responding individuals largely shift assets across accounts (crowd-out), and (c) subsidies do not reach passive individuals who are least prepared for retirement

Limitation: taxable saving measures are noisy (asset-return and durable purchase timing), which reduces precision for some level-based crowd-out estimates; MPS and threshold/instrumental approaches mitigate but do not eliminate imprecision
